unnormalised: Electoral reforms in India are constantly debated, aiming to strengthen our democracy and ensure fairer representation. It's a crucial topic under Public Policy & Governance.
normalised: Electoral reforms in India are constantly debated, aiming to strengthen our democracy and ensure fairer representation. It's a crucial topic under Public Policy and Governance.

unnormalised: One major area of focus is campaign finance. Think about the massive amounts of money splashed during elections; transparency and limits on corporate donations are vital. Stricter enforcement of the Model Code of Conduct, especially regarding hate speech, is also paramount. Remember the uproar surrounding inflammatory remarks during the 2019 Lok Sabha elections?

unnormalised: Another crucial aspect is electoral roll management. Ensuring accurate and updated voter lists, minimizing bogus votes, and facilitating easier registration for migrants (like many Biharis working in Maharashtra) are essential. The Election Commission of India has been making strides in this area using technology.

unnormalised: Criminalization of politics is a persistent problem. Fast-tracking cases against politicians with criminal records and disqualifying those convicted of serious offences would be a significant step. Even a Bollywood film like "Youngistaan" touched upon the public's disillusionment with corrupt politicians.

unnormalised: Beyond these, reforms like electronic voting machines (EVMs) with Voter Verified Paper Audit Trail (VVPAT) and greater use of technology can enhance transparency and reduce rigging. State funding of elections has also been proposed to level the playing field and reduce reliance on black money. The debate continues on the best ways to achieve a cleaner and more representative electoral process in Bharat. Reforming isn't easy, but is the bedrock of a healthy democracy.
